 HUMAN RIGHTS COUNCIL CALLS FOR LGBT WEB SITE ACCESS FOR STUDENTS
 OIA Newsdesk
 
 
 
 
 WEST PALM BEACH - The Palm Beach County Human Rights Council called on the ACLU and Lambda Legal to force the Palm Beach County School District to stop blocking students' access to LGBT web sites.
 
 The school district has declared millions of web sites as unappropriate because they promote violence, racism and pornography.
 
 In doing so, the district has blocked access to gay and lesbian advocacy web sites, including pbchrc.org, the one belonging to the Palm Beach County Human Rights Council, a local GLBT advocacy group.
 
 "It is unfair that our site is being censored, while students have access to anti-gay sites," said Rand Hoch, founder of the Palm Beach County Human Rights Council. "The district is also blocking both the Compass and the P-Flag web sites."Compass is the local LGBT community center which runs numerous programs for LGBT youth in Palm Beach County.
 
 Students are granted access to many sites opposing gay rights such as the American Family Association, Focus on the Family and the Traditional Values Coalition.
 
 "The Council has asked both the ACLU and Lambda Legal to consider challenging the school board's policy," Hoch said. "Both organizations have experience in combating similar censorship elsewhere in America."
 
 High school teacher Michael Woods, who served as the sponsor for Boynton Beach High's Gay-Straight Alliance last year, said blocking gay advocacy web sites sends a negative message to students.
 
 "One of the things we tell kids is that when you hit the firewall, it's a bad thing," Woods said. "I agree with filtering, but now they are going to see gay/lesbian and associate that with something that is bad."
 
 Advocates also say the sites provide information and resources for students, who may be uncomfortable soliciting it from adults.
 
 "We need to recognize the computer has become a community tool for students to reach out," said Tony Plakas, president of the West Palm Beach-based Compass, a gay and lesbian center.
 
 James Green, an ACLU lawyer, plans to review the case this week. The ACLU has sued in the past over censorship on the Web. In 2002, the Georgia ACLU filed a free-speech lawsuit on behalf of the Gay Guardian newspaper, claiming that a public library barred the newspaper from the library's free literature area. 
 
 "If their blocking software prevents kids, particularly middle and high school kids, from having access to information about gay rights and public health issues, but on the other hand allow access to religious group Web sites that are hostile to gay and lesbian legal rights and public health, that constitutes censorship," Green said. 
 
 "That's a lot of power, to decide what information is given," said Rand Hoch, founder of the Palm Beach County Human Rights Council. "There has to be a better way the school district can strike a balance than blocking all access to all students."
 
 School board member Paulette Burdick agrees. 
 
 "Perhaps the only good source of information in regard to this sensitive issue is the Internet," Burdick said. "We need to figure out a way to address this." [5/9/06]
